By distributing and installing these energy-efficient stoves, the project aims to reduce particulate matter (PM2.5) emissions, minimize household air pollution, and enhance the overall efficiency of cooking processes. The core technology utilized in this initiative is the deployment of ICS, designed to optimize fuel consumption and lower greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions associated with cooking activities. Initially located in Odisha and Jharkhand, India, the project plans to expand to other regions in the future. Through the adoption of ICS, significant reductions in GHG emissions are expected, contributing to a cleaner environment. Prior to the project, households likely relied on traditional cooking methods that contribute to air pollution and GHG emissions. The project estimates substantial annual average GHG emission reductions of 2,48,379 tCO2e and total reductions and removals of 17,38,650 tCO2e, highlighting the positive impact of transitioning to ICS. By promoting sustainable cooking practices, the project aims to create healthier living conditions for households and support global climate change mitigation efforts.
